parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> global

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Math - Geometry

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> [[Image:distance2D.jpg|400px|right]]
Returns a distance in meters between [[Object]]s, [[Position]]s or [[Location]]s.
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> important </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> If positions are supplied as arguments, the coordinates are treated as [[PositionATL]] if over the land and as [[PositionASLW]] if over the sea. If [[Position2D]] is supplied, z is assumed 0. If you need distance between two [[Position3D]] coordinates, use [[vectorDistance]].</value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> param1 '''distance''' param2

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> param1: [[Object]] or [[Array]] in format [[PositionAGL]] or [[Position2D]]
</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> param2: [[Object]] or [[Array]] in format [[PositionAGL]] or [[Position2D]]

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]] -  Distance in meters or 1e10 if distance cannot be calculated

</value></part><part><name> s2</name>=<value> location1 '''distance''' location2

</value></part><part><name>p21</name>=<value>  location1: [[Location]] or [[Array]] in format [[Position]] or [[Position2D]]
</value></part><part><name>p22</name>=<value>  location2: [[Location]] or [[Array]] in format [[Position]] or [[Position2D]]

</value></part><part><name>r2</name>=<value> [[Number]] - Distance in meters or 1e10 if distance cannot be calculated
  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_meters = [[player]] [[distance]] _object;</code>
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>_meters = [[player]] [[distance]] [1,2,3];</code>
</value></part><part><name>x3</name>=<value> <code>_meters = [1,2,3] [[distance]] [4,5,6];</code>
</value></part><part><name>x4</name>=<value> <code>_meters = [[position]] [[player]] [[distance]] [[nearestLocation]] [<ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/></ext>[[position]] [[player]], "hill"];</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[distanceSqr]], [[vectorDistance]], [[distance2D]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">

<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment><dd class="notedate">Posted on Feb 14, 2007 - 12:00</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Sudden Death|Sudden Death]]<dd class="note">distance to position3D (array) doesnt work with OFP, only objects

Armed Assault:
position3D (array) and object works

<dd class="notedate">Posted on Mar 10, 2010 - 12:00</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Rommel|Rommel]]<dd class="note">This returns the map distance, not the vector distance, [0,0,0] distance [0,0,1] can be >1 or <1, not exactly 1; unlike the vector math.

<dd class="notedate">Posted on Aug 03, 2012 - 10:15</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Ignoues01|Igneous01]]<dd class="note">If a position in format [x, y, z] is provided for both arguments, distance also checks the z dimension as well. Ie:
player distance [0,0,200]
will return 200, if the player is at this position at ground/sea level.

<dd class="notedate">Posted on March 22, 2014</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:AgentRev01|AgentRev]]<dd class="note">When objects are supplied as arguments, distance is calculated from their model center (object modelToWorld [0,0,0]), and not the position returned by getPos/ATL/ASL.<br>
However, this is not relevant for units, as their model center matches their world position.

<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment></dl>
